awd_titl_txt: Arctic Plant Phenology - Learning through Engaged Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The PI will develop and pilot a scalable strategy for involving educators in polar research and making data from a polar research program accessible to students. Plans include engaging grades 6-12 and undergraduate science educators in a long-term, ongoing research project in Greenland that examines changes in the phenology (e.g. seasonal life cycle events - in this case, the onset of springtime plant growth) of arctic plants and how this relates to climate. Educators and students will conduct similar observations and experiments in their local environment and will contribute their data to the ongoing research efforts. Participants will consist of approximately 24 middle school, high school, and undergraduate educators from schools across a range of geographical locations and school districts serving underrepresented and underserved students. 

The PI will conduct a workshop each year with the educators and will develop online resources that will be available to the educators. Educators will be engaged in an ongoing study of plant phenology at a field site near Kangerlussuaq, Greenland, and they will learn observational and experimental methods of studying plant phenology that they can use with their students in their local environment.  Educators from Fort Lewis College, Colorado, which is a primarily undergraduate institution; Blue Hill Consolidated School, Maine; and St. Paul Island, Alaska, will participate during this project. Additionally, the development of online resources will provide access to data from long-term research on arctic plant phenology, related lesson plans and media representations of research activities in Greenland to an expanded network of educators. These on-line resources will serve educational needs beyond the duration of this project. The proposed activities present outstanding opportunities for the involvement of student groups, including Native American and Alaskan Aleut students, in research through hands-on training and inquiry-based educational experiences.

por.por_cntn:
The APPLES Project was launched in 2016 with the goal of providing hands-on training in climate change research methods and instruction to K-12 educators through annual workshops. Over the project duration, the APPLES team held four national workshops and trained a total of 50 teachers in 19 U.S. states. In the second year of the project, three of these teachers accompanied members of the APPLES team to a long-term research site near Kangerlussuaq, Greenland, where they had the opportunity to learn first-hand about ongoing research at the site on plant and animal responses to arctic climate change. These teachers subsequently became peer mentors in later APPLES workshops.

Workshop training included instructional modules on the basics of climate change science and how its impacts are studied, an introduction to systems-thinking, challenges to teaching about climate change, using a card game to teach the difference between climate and weather, introductory plant ecology, ethics of data sharing, and the use of time lapse cameras and passive warming chambers (open-top greenhouses) to study plant responses to climate change. Participating teachers were also provided with time lapse cameras and greenhouse materials for use in school yard applications as well as access to long-term research data from the study site in Greenland for use in classroom lessons.

A project website (www.applesproject.org) was developed to allow participating teachers to share lesson plans related to the study of climate change impacts, ask and answer questions through an interactive forum, and remain connected with each other and with other members of the APPLES team. The project website also provides an archive of workshop materials and access to other resources outside the APPLES project that are relevant to the study of, and instruction in, climate change impacts.

Award funds also supported the collection and analysis of data on plant phenological (i.e., growth timing) dynamics at the study site near Kangerlussuaq. This research contributed to the mentoring of two graduate student projects, the publication of several peer-reviewed journal articles and one book (Time in Ecology - a theoretical framework) on plant and animal responses to climate change in the Arctic, and numerous international conference presentations by the APPLES team. Novel insights and data resulting from these efforts were also incorporated into a course on climate change ecology at the University of California, Davis.

Finally, the success of the APPLES project was used to leverage internal funds at the University of California, Davis, for development of a polar studies curriculum and to support collaborative efforts with the University of Oxford (UK) to continue research on plant and animal responses to climate change at the Kangerlussuaq study site. The APPLES team intends to seek additional funding to continue its training misssion through future national and international workshops.
